issues.description: Inner-artifact inconsistency in the problem statement: the textual description and tasks refer to a Lecture class, but the UML diagram declares the class as "Course". This mismatch between the class name shown in the UML and the rest of the problem statement (and the provided template/solution files) can confuse students about the expected class name and where to add attributes/constructors/methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the class name consistent in the problem statement UML and text. Replace the UML class declaration 'class Course' with 'class Lecture' (and update any labels in the UML to reference Lecture) so it matches the textual tasks and the template/solution files. Alternatively, if the intended name is Course, update the textual tasks and template/solution to use Course instead of Lecture.

issues.description: The UML diagram in the problem statement names the class 'Course' while the textual description, example outputs, the template code and the solution all use the class name 'Lecture'. This inconsistent class name for the same conceptual entity (the lecture/course record) can confuse students when they try to map the UML to the provided code and tests—students may wonder whether to implement a class named Course or Lecture.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the UML class from 'Course' to 'Lecture' in the problem statement so the UML, textual description, template and solution consistently refer to the same class name. (Alternatively, if 'Course' was intended, rename the template/solution classes to 'Course' and update all textual references—prefer the first option to match the existing text and code.)
